text: - Hi, welcome back to our masterclass
on data governance with AWS.
I'm Kevin Lewis.

And now I'd like to talk
about the relationship
of governance to artificial intelligence
and machine learning.

First, I'm gonna use the
terms artificial intelligence

and machine learning
somewhat interchangeably.
Technically, there's differences.
Machine learning is a way
to implement artificial intelligence,
but for our purposes,
we can just use the terms interchangeably.

So thinking about the
relationship of governance
to machine learning,

you know, let's think about
it in a few different ways.
First, let's think about data governance

as we've been talking
about it to this point,
and how it relates to supporting
machine learning capability,

and then let's talk about
special considerations
as it relates to machine learning,

that adds additional
responsibilities to our program
that may not be in place
with a data governance program.
And then let's talk a little bit
about generative AI, in particular,

and some of the things
that we wanna think about
as it relates to generative AI
and the special considerations there.
So the first thing to understand

is that all of the things
that we've been talking about

as it relates to data governance
apply to machine learning.
So what I'm saying here is,

as you think about how
to apply machine learning
to produce value in your organization,

you're going to discover
that the underlying data

needs to be in a condition
to meet the needs
of the specific initiatives
associated with machine learning,

things like, you know,
master data management,
when we talk about linking customer data
or product data from a variety of sources,
when we think about regulatory compliance,
and data lineage,
and all of those same things,
we don't wanna have to rediscover the need
for data governance as a result
of building machine learning capability.
So it's better to go into the program
knowing that there should be a partnership

between the data governance
program and machine learning,

just as the data governance
program supports applications
and analytics more generally.
In fact, with a lot of investment
in artificial intelligence,
if the data governance is not yet in place
the way you would like it to be...
You know, we talked about using,

you know, funding and
supporting funded initiatives,
if there is a lot of interest
in funding behind artificial intelligence
and machine learning,
you can actually use that
to drive your data governance program
and begin the process of maturing it,

and, likewise, use that to
support the value proposition

outside of the machine
learning capability.
So, you know, again, the main point here

is to think about data
governance as getting data

in the condition to meet the
needs of business initiatives.

It applies to artificial
intelligence and machine learning,

just as it does to other
analytics and applications.
In fact, some surveys indicate that,

you know, 20% or fewer
machine learning models
ever make it to production.

You know, so one of the
things to think about

is what will it take
to actually get a model
confidently into production?

And that is when things like
data quality management,
and master data management,

and, you know, generally
the reliability of data

and protecting the data
becomes even more crucial,

because it's one thing to
experiment with a model,
but it's quite another
to get that implemented into production.
So that's the first thing,

is make sure we're
aligning these programs.
In fact, when we talked about a roadmap
and what a roadmap looks like,

think of artificial intelligence
and machine learning
as within the application track.

You can literally fold these
use cases into that roadmap
along with other use cases
to be supported by similar data.

It doesn't have to be a complete
machine learning roadmap.
It can be machine learning

embedded into a larger
data strategy roadmap,
and then that emphasizes the point
that we wanna make data governance
a part of that overall process,

just like with the other
capabilities we talked about.
Okay, so that's the relationship

between data governance and
machine learning in general.

Now, let's talk about the
special considerations
as it relates to machine learning.

So one special consideration
for machine learning
is the new kinds of data structures

that we want to bring into
our governance program.

So, for example, let's
think about feature stores.

Just like we talked about
not wanting to do the same
data management work over and over again,

and integrating data
from multiple sources,
and building confidence in that data,

and doing it over and over
again for various initiatives,

we find the same thing
in model development
when it comes to building the structures

that are essential specifically
for machine learning,
like feature stores.
So rather than building feature stores
just for one individual use case,

if I have a roadmap of
where this is going,
I can think about the kinds of features

that are going to be needed
across a wide variety
of machine learning models,

and then I can use my
data governance program

to think cross-functionally
about building feature stores
that can be used across those use cases.

And just like we talked
about with data governance,

we don't have to build
out all possible features
all at once,

but as we roll out more
and more use cases,
rather than starting from scratch,

we can build those feature
stores and extended them,
and extended them,
and enhanced them,
and things like that,

so we end up with an
inventory of feature stores
that are available for,

again, a variety of
machine learning models.

And so the same things
that we talked about,

where, you know, profiling
the data for quality,
and monitoring for quality,
and things like that,
when it comes to data lakes,
and data warehouses, and so on,
can also apply to feature stores
as a part of the architecture.

The other things that
you need to think about
are regulatory compliance.
So within our data governance program,

you know, we already want to
look at security and privacy
and all of that.

There's new legislation
being proposed all the time
as it relates to machine learning,
and we're gonna see more and more of that.
So much like we are taking a look at,
you know, regulatory compliance
as it relates to data in general,

there's different and
special considerations
as it relates to machine learning,

and just looking at it
from a company policy,
and an ethics perspective,
and, you know, things
like keeping our customer data private,
and using data appropriately,
this has to be a very conscious track
within any machine learning program.

So let's talk, then, about
generative AI in particular.

You know, this is obviously a
profound change in technology,

and so, again, there are still
a lot of the same elements

underneath in terms of
pulling data together
and relying on the data
that feeds a generative AI,
just like it would any other use case.

But again, there are
special considerations
as it relates to generative AI.
So things like unlabeled data.

So you have labeled data
and you have unlabeled data.
We talked earlier, for example,

about claims processing
or claims adjudication.
So imagine now that you have generative AI
fishing through a lot of freeform text

to support the process
of adjudicating claims.
Well, now, you know, the completeness

and the accuracy of the
information inside the claims

that are gonna be used
to feed these models,
both in terms of inference,

which is sort of using
the models in production,
but also in terms of,

you know, training and
customizing, fine tuning,
this is gonna take on added importance.
Or you can think about...
You can think about, like, a CRM system.
So if you are gonna use generative AI

to enhance your relationship
with your customer

and you have information that's
captured in a CRM system,

and there's, again, a
lot of freeform text,

a lot of information that can
be used to both an inference,
and in fine tuning,
and things like that,
the governance over that information,
and the collection of that information,
and having confidence in it,
is gonna be all the more important.

So we talked before about
that we need a business
and IT partnership.
So if we are using that information,
like in a CRM system,
to feed models in one way or another,
then it's gonna be all the more important

to have a partnership
between IT and the business,

where there may be new
training that's required,

there may be new processes
that need to take place,
because the operational processes
that produce this information
need to be substantial enough

to feed these models
so that they can make,
you know, accurate recommendations,

and they can become a part of
the overall business process.
Also, you're gonna have, again,
additional regulatory issues,
because things like visibility
into what these models are doing,
there needs to be adequate documentation
about what is being done inside the models
and how they're producing their results.
So you're gonna see, again,
more and more regulations,

specifically around the
use of generative AI
and business processes.
Okay, so the special considerations
as it relates to machine learning,
things we need to think about in addition

to the relationship
between machine learning
and data governance,
is the the governance
of the machine learning process itself,
so, you know, building, testing,
deploying models into production,
those kinds of things need monitoring.
There needs to be a process to make that
as efficient as possible,
so that it's as repeatable as possible,

so we can efficiently go
through the whole process

and end up with these
models in production.
We call that MLOps.
So institutionalizing the process
of going through all of those phases,
and making it as effective as possible,
supported by technology,
is something we wanna think about.
Also, documentation.

So when we are building
machine learning models,

and, again, not just for
regulatory compliance,
but in general,

so that we have a handle on
the machine learning process,
every machine learning model,

especially if it's going to
be deployed in production,

is gonna have to have some
documentation associated with it,

things like, what are the
special ethical considerations
as it relates to this model?
Things like bias

and things that we need
to be concerned about.
How was the model trained?
What data was used?
What kind of freshness do we expect
in terms of the data to feed this model?
So we wanna be able to automate that
as much as we possibly can,
but it's also gonna require some level of,
you know, governance to make sure

that we're documenting
these models adequately,
so we have confidence in what we're doing,

and we have a record
of what the model does,
and how it's managed,
and all of that.
With generative AI,

there's some additional
things to think about.
So which model to use,
under what circumstances there.

It's not just one
foundation model to consider
to meet the needs of use cases.

There's a wide variety of
foundation models for various uses
and they're each good at different things.

So applying governance
to the selection process

of which model to use
under what circumstances
is something that's gonna be very helpful,

or even chaining multiple models
together in an application.
So the inventory and capability

of the various models that
you use in your organization,
how they're customized,

how they're chained
together in applications,

these are things you don't
wanna have to figure out
with every single project.

These are things that you
have to establish as standards
and, of course, continuously improve,
and we wanna make that a part
of the overall governance process.

Also, monitoring for things
like bias and toxicity

and some of the things that
are somewhat unpredictable

about what these generative
AI models can produce.

There's things we can do to
proactively monitor the output
of what these models do,

so that we are being careful
to monitor for things
like bias and toxicity.
However, you also have to be careful.

Just like everything
else we've talked about,
this is a balancing act.
So you don't want to,

you know, restrict the
model so significantly

that you're missing an
opportunity to learn something.
So let's take for example,
you know, product reviews, okay?

So maybe you're looking
for product reviews,

and social media comments
on your products,
and you're bringing that together,

and bringing that into
a generative AI model
to make a determination

about what the feedback
is on particular products,
well, maybe you're gonna learn something

about products that might
be a little unpleasant
to learn about.
And if you do that,

you wanna be careful
not to change the model
so much that you don't pick up

on very important strategic,
you know, feedback
that you get from these models,

and then you end up, you
know, losing that insight.
So, yeah, so, monitoring for bias,
monitoring for toxicity,

but being very careful to be
open to learning something
about what it is that,

you know, that you're
trying to learn about.

You have to be conscious of
what's happening with your data.

So these models that are
being used for generative AI,
these are typically pre-built models
that you can then customize,

but what is happening to
the data that you're using,

both in inference and
in terms of fine tuning,
where is that data going?
Is the model provider using that data
without your customer's knowledge
to continuously improve their own models?

You need to be conscious of
what's happening with the data
that you're providing to these models,

and you wanna be able to
protect your customer's data
and your own sensitive data
from being used by model providers
without your knowledge or consent.
In summary, the main thing to do

is to make sure that your
data governance program
is supporting your machine learning
and artificial intelligence capability

just as it is other
analytics capabilities.

And you need to add to the
program things that are necessary
for governance of machine learning itself
and for traditional machine learning,
as well as generative AI.

So we wanna make that part
of one overall program,
rather than discovering the need

for the underlying data
governance separately
as part of your AI/ML program.
You wanna proactively
consider how these things link together.

We also talked previously
about the analytics community
and organizing the analytics community.
We should make machine learning
a part of that wider community,
because these capabilities
are gonna serve the similar constituents,
as you will, within the analytics world,
so we wanna make machine learning
a part of the analytics community

and we also wanna link
it to data governance.
(upbeat electronic music)
